body: {"blocks":[{"key":"4rinc","text":"Use only few datapoints. One fix to the above problem of kinks is to use fewer datapoints, since loss functions that contain kinks (e.g. due to use of ReLUs or margin losses etc.) will have fewer kinks with fewer datapoints, so it is less likely for you to cross one when you perform the finite different approximation. Moreover, if your gradcheck for only ~2 or 3 datapoints then you would almost certainly gradcheck for an entire batch. Using very few datapoints also makes your gradient check faster and more efficient.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":23,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":23,"length":499,"style":"color-rgb(0,0,0)"},{"offset":23,"length":499,"style":"bgcolor-rgb(255,255,255)"},{"offset":23,"length":499,"style":"fontsize-16"},{"offset":23,"length":499,"style":"fontfamily-Roboto, sans-serif"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{"text-align":"justify"}},{"key":"5dsf1","text":"Stick around active range of floating point. It’s a good idea to read through “What Every Computer Scientist Should Know About Floating-Point Arithmetic”, as it may demystify your errors and enable you to write more careful code. For example, in neural nets it can be common to normalize the loss function over the batch. However, if your gradients per datapoint are very small, then additionally dividing them by the number of data points is starting to give very small numbers, which in turn will lead to more numerical issues. This is why I like to always print the raw numerical/analytic gradient, and make sure that the numbers you are comparing are not extremely small (e.g. roughly 1e-10 and smaller in absolute value is worrying). If they are you may want to temporarily scale your loss function up by a constant to bring them to a “nicer” range where floats are more dense - ideally on the order of 1.0, where your float exponent is 0.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":77,"style":"color-rgb(0,0,0)"},{"offset":78,"length":305,"style":"color-rgb(0,0,0)"},{"offset":384,"length":12,"style":"color-rgb(0,0,0)"},{"offset":397,"length":547,"style":"color-rgb(0,0,0)"},{"offset":0,"length":77,"style":"bgcolor-rgb(255,255,255)"},{"offset":78,"length":305,"style":"bgcolor-rgb(255,255,255)"},{"offset":384,"length":12,"style":"bgcolor-rgb(255,255,255)"},{"offset":397,"length":547,"style":"bgcolor-rgb(255,255,255)"},{"offset":0,"length":77,"style":"fontsize-16"},{"offset":78,"length":305,"style":"fontsize-16"},{"offset":384,"length":12,"style":"fontsize-16"},{"offset":397,"length":547,"style":"fontsize-16"},{"offset":0,"length":77,"style":"fontfamily-Roboto, sans-serif"},{"offset":78,"length":305,"style":"fontfamily-Roboto, sans-serif"},{"offset":384,"length":12,"style":"fontfamily-Roboto, sans-serif"},{"offset":397,"length":547,"style":"fontfamily-Roboto, sans-serif"},{"offset":0,"length":43,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":78,"length":75,"style":"color-rgb(32,92,170)"},{"offset":384,"length":12,"style":"ITALIC"}],"entityRanges":[{"offset":78,"length":75,"key":0}],"data":{}},{"key":"9ldts","text":"Use double precision. A common pitfall is using single precision floating point to compute gradient check. It is often that case that you might get high relative errors (as high as 1e-2) even with a correct gradient implementation. In my experience I’ve sometimes seen my relative errors plummet from 1e-2 to 1e-8 by switching to double precision.\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":20,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":20,"length":327,"style":"color-rgb(0,0,0)"},{"offset":20,"length":327,"style":"bgcolor-rgb(255,255,255)"},{"offset":20,"length":327,"style":"fontsize-16"},{"offset":20,"length":327,"style":"fontfamily-Roboto, sans-serif"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ab5vn","text":"\n","type":"header-one","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{"text-align":"start"}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"LINK","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19957-01/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html","title":"“What Every Computer Scientist Should Know About Floating-Point Arithmetic”","targetOption":"","_map":{"type":"LINK","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19957-01/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html","title":"“What Every Computer Scientist Should Know About Floating-Point Arithmetic”","targetOption":""}}}}}}
